sen.j: 日野 俊光（ひのとしみつ、文応元年（1260年） - 嘉暦元年5月15日 (旧暦)（1326年））は、鎌倉時代の公卿。
sen.e: Toshimitsu HINO (1260 - June 23, 1326 [表記の変更]) was a Kugyo (high court noble), who lived during the Kamakura period.
Toshimitsu HINO (1260 - June 23, 1326) was a Court noble who lived during the Kamakura period.
Toshimitsu HINO (1260 - June 23, 1326) was a Court noble who lived during the Kamakura period.
He was the 17th family head of the Hino family.
He was the 17th head of the Hino family.
sen.cmt: 17代当主→the 17th head（"family"が重複しているので変更しました。）
sen.e: He was the 17th head of the Hino family.
He was the son of the 16th family head, Sukenobu HINO.
He was the son of the 16th family head, Sukenobu HINO.

sen.j: 子に日野資名、日野資朝、日野資明、賢俊らがいる。
sen.e: His sons were Sukena HINO, Suketomo HINO, Sukeaki HINO and Kenshun, among others.
He was the father of Sukena HINO, Suketomo HINO, Sukeaki HINO, Kenshun and so on.
sen.cmt: 子に～らがいる→He was the father of ～ and so on
sen.e: He was the father of Sukena HINO, Suketomo HINO, Sukeaki HINO, Kenshun and so on.
He was ranked Gon Dainagon (provisional chief counselor of state).
He held the office of Gon Dainagon (provisional chief counselor of state).
sen.cmt: 位は→He held the office of
sen.e: He held the office of Gon Dainagon (provisional chief counselor of state).

sen.j: 右衛門督・文章博士・右大弁・左大弁・蔵人頭等を歴任。
sen.e: He held various posts such as Uemon no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards), Monjo hakase (professor of literature), Udaiben (Controller of the Right), Sadaiben (Controller of the Left), and Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain).

sen.e: He held various posts such as Uemon no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards), Monjo hakase (professor of literature), Udaiben (Controller of the Right), Sadaiben (Controller of the Left), Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain) and so on.

sen.j: 永仁3年（1295年）参議、同5年（1297年）権中納言、文保元年（1317年）に権大納言に至る（同年、辞職）。
sen.e: In 1295 he was appointed Sangi (councilor) and in 1297 Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state), and finally he was ascended to Gon Dainagon (provisional chief councilor of state) (he resigned from the post in the same year)

He was appointed to Sangi (councilor) in 1295, to Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state) in 1297, and finally to Gon Dainagon (provisional chief councilor of state) in 1317 (resigned in the same year).
sen.cmt: 年号を各役職の後に置いたほうがわかりやすいので、変更し、文尾にピリオドを付けました。
sen.e: He was appointed to Sangi (councilor) in 1295, to Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state) in 1297, and finally to Gon Dainagon (provisional chief councilor of state) in 1317 (resigned in the same year).

sen.j: 伏見天皇の近臣であり、後伏見天皇・花園天皇・光明天皇の乳父である。
sen.e: He was a trusted vassal of Emperor Fushimi, and the memoto (foster father) of Emperor Gofushimi, Emperor Hanazono and Emperor Komyo.
He was a trusted vassal of Emperor Fushimi, and was the foster father of the Emperor Gofushimi, Emperor Hanazono and Emperor Komyo.
He was a trusted vassal of Emperor Fushimi, and was the foster father of the Emperor Gofushimi, Emperor Hanazono and Emperor Komyo.

sen.j: 大覚寺統の信任も厚く、後宇多天皇の院司もつとめた。
sen.e: He was highly trusted by Daikakuji-to (imperial lineage starting with Emperor Kameyama), and he also served Emperor Gouda as Inshi (an official of the In no cho [Retired Emperor's Office]).
Since he was highly trusted by Daikakuji-to (imperial lineage starting with the Emperor Kameyama), he also served the Emperor Gouda as Inshi (an official of the In no cho (Retired Emperor's Office)).
Since he was highly trusted by Daikakuji-to (imperial lineage starting with the Emperor Kameyama), he also served the Emperor Gouda as Inshi (an official of the In no cho (Retired Emperor's Office)).

sen.j: 正中 (日本)2年（1325年）から2年間、勅使として鎌倉に下り、皇位継承問題をめぐり幕府との折衝に当たったが、翌年の嘉暦元年（1326年）5月15日、任半ばにして関東で没した。
sen.e: In 1325, he went down to Kamakura and took charge of the negotiation with the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) about the Imperial succession during two years, however, on June 23 (表記の変更) of the next year 1336, he died in the Kanto region during his term.

Although he went down to Kamakura as an Imperial envoy in 1325 and intended to take charge of negotiating with the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) over the Imperial succession for two years, he died in the Kanto region during his term on June 23 of the next year 1326.
sen.cmt: 勅使→Imperial envoy（訳抜けしていたので、補いました。）「2年間、～折衝に当ったが」→Although ～ and intended to take charge of negotiating ～ for two years（"Although"で始まる文章に変更しました。また、実際は、鎌倉に下った翌年に死去しているため、2年間折衝には当っていないので、"intended to"としました。）翌年の嘉暦元年（1326年）5月15日→June of the next year 1326
sen.e: Although he went down to Kamakura as an Imperial envoy in 1325 and intended to take charge of negotiating with the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) over the Imperial succession for two years, he died in the Kanto region during his term on June 23 of the next year 1326.

sen.j: 各方面の歌合にも度々参加し、嘉元百首・文保百首の作者に列なる。
sen.e: He participated in various utaawase (poetry contests), and he was one of the authors of The 100-poem compilation of the Kagen era as well as The 100-poem compilation of the Bumpo era.
He often participated in various kinds of utaawase (poetry contests), and he ranked as one of the poets of The 100-poem compilation of the Kagen era and The 100-poem compilation of the Bunpo era.
sen.cmt: 各方面→various kinds of度々→often（訳抜けしていましたので、補いました。）文保→Bunpo
sen.e: He often participated in various kinds of utaawase (poetry contests), and he ranked as one of the poets of The 100-poem compilation of the Kagen era and The 100-poem compilation of the Bunpo era.
The first appearance of his name is found in Shin Gosenshu (New Later Collection of Japanese Poetry).
sen.cmt: 新後撰集→Shin Gosenshu (New Later Collection of Japanese Poetry)としました。
sen.e: His poem first appeared in Shingosenshu (New Later Collection of Japanese Poetry).
sen.cmt: 新後撰集→Shingosenshu (New Later Collection of Japanese Poetry)
sen.e: His poem first appeared in Shingosenshu (New Later Collection of Japanese Poetry).
Out of his poems, 33 pieces were selected for the various compilations by Imperial command.
33 out of his poems, in total, were selected and contained in Chokusen wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command).
sen.cmt: 「勅撰」→Chokusen wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command)
sen.e: 33 out of his poems, in total, were selected and contained in Chokusen wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command).
He published a personal collection of poetry, "Shunkoshu (俊光集)."
He compiled his poems in a private collection, "Shunkoshu."

sen.e: He compiled his poems in a private collection, "Shunkoshu."
